In a monoid $M$, an element $b \in M$ is called an inverse of a given element $a \in M$ if $ab = e = ba$. The element $b$, if it exists, is uniquely determined by $a$ and is denoted by $a^{-1}$.

For a group $G$ and a subset $X \subset G$, the subgroup $H$ generated by $X$ is defined as the intersection of all subgroups of $G$ containing $X$. It is the unique smallest subgroup of $G$ containing $X$ and consists of all elements of the form $x_{1}^{\varepsilon_{1}} \cdot \ldots \cdot x_{n}^{\varepsilon_{n}}$ where $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n} \in X$ and $\varepsilon_{1}, \ldots, $\varepsilon_{n} \in \{1,-1\}$, with $n$ varying over $\mathbb{N}$.
For a ring R, the set of multiplicatively invertible elements is denoted by R*. These elements are called the units of R.
A ring homomorphism $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R'$ is called an epimorphism if it is surjective.
Let $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R'$ be a ring homomorphism. The image of $\varphi$, denoted $\operatorname{im} \varphi$, is defined as $\varphi(R)$, which is a subring of $R'$.
Submodules of an A-module M are defined similarly to subspaces in vector spaces, where a submodule N of M is a subset that is closed under the operations of M.

Kronecker's construction defines an extension field by taking the quotient of the polynomial ring of the base field by the ideal generated by an irreducible polynomial. The residue class of the indeterminate in this quotient field is a zero of the polynomial, allowing the successive adjoining of zeros of polynomials to the base field.

An element $b \in B$ is integral over $A$ with respect to a ring homomorphism $\varphi: A \longrightarrow B$ if it satisfies any of the equivalent conditions: (i) there exists an integral equation of $b$ over $A$, i.e., an equation of type $f(b)=0$ for a monic polynomial $f \in A[X]$, (ii) the subring $A[b] \subset B$, viewed as an $A$-module, is finitely generated, (iii) viewing $B$ as an $A$-module, there exists a finitely generated submodule $M=\sum_{i=1}^{n} A m_{i} \subset B$ such that $1 \in M$ and $b M \subset M$.

An algebraic closure $\\[\overline{\mathbb{F}}_p\]$ of a finite field $\\[\mathbb{F}_p\]$ is a field that contains $\\[\mathbb{F}_p\]$ and all its algebraic extensions. It is used to view the fields $\\[\mathbb{F}_{p^n}\]$ as subfields.

A ring \(R\) is called Noetherian if every ascending chain of ideals \(\mathfrak{a}_{1} \subset \mathfrak{a}_{2} \subset \ldots \subset R\) becomes stationary after finitely many steps, or equivalently, every ideal of \(R\) is finitely generated.
A cycle involving $r$ elements is called an $r$-cycle and is denoted as $\pi = (x_{1}, \ldots, x_{r})$.
A subset is a set where all of its elements are also contained within another set.

Generalization_Specialization_Relationsh.Explanation: A subgroup generated by a set (ID: 1) is a specific type of subset (ID: 11) where the subset also satisfies the group axioms and is closed under group operations.
A submodule (ID: 5) is a specific type of subset (ID: 11) where the subset also satisfies the module axioms and is closed under module operations.
